SENT.plain: A case of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is reported
A 48-year-old man visited our hospital because of proteinuria
He had suffered from thrombosis and had high titers of antibodies to beta2-glycoprotein I (abeta2GPI) and anticardiolipin antibodies (aCLIgG) and thrombocytopenia
We started anticoagulation therapy using warfarin combined with prednisolone
Although platelet count was improved, the titers of anti-beta2GPI and aCLIgG still remained high
Therefore, double-filtration plasmapheresis (DFPP) was carried out to remove the antibodies
After the treatment with DFPP, cyclophosphamide was administered
These therapies resulted in lower titers of abeta2GPI and aCLIgG and no more thrombosis occurred
A combination therapy using warfarin, prednisolone, cyclophosphamide and DFPP might be effective for the treatment of patients with APS
